column3: Level 1 (Foundational): Basic awareness and foundational knowledge. Applies established approaches with guidance, contributing to team outcomes through well-scoped tasks.
column4: Level 2 (Intermediate): Working knowledge and consistent application. Operates independently, using sound judgement to drive outcomes with minimal oversight.
column5: Level 3 (Advanced): Comprehensive understanding and independent application. Influences multiple teams, elevates quality and systems, and guides others.
column6: Level 4 (Expert): Complete mastery, innovation, and leadership. Sets standards across the organisation, develops new approaches, and shapes how design is practiced at scale.

column3: Aligns their work with the broader strategy and understands how customer needs and business goals shape design direction. Connects day-to-day design decisions to strategic intent by articulating how their work supports user needs and business goals. Brings fresh perspectives by exploring multiple approaches and questioning obvious or default solutions.
column4: Influences team strategy by clarifying the problem space, reframing challenges, and using insights to guide which problems the team prioritises. Translates insights into clear problem framing and helps the team stay focused on the most meaningful opportunities. Reframes problems to introduce fresh perspectives and challenge conventional ways of thinking.
column5: Influences the strategy of a vertical by defining the design direction and establishing the strategic approach for that area. Shapes strategic conversations using insights, narratives, design vision and experience principles to influence direction and uncover new opportunity spaces. Unlocks new opportunities by reframing complex problem spaces and imagining alternative models, workflows, or experiences.
column6: Defines the company-wide experience vision and ensures design meaningfully influences long-term business strategy. Co-creates strategy across verticals by shaping design direction, long-term experience vision, and organisational priorities through customer insight, storytelling, and a compelling design-led narrative. Identifies high-leverage problems others may overlook and sets new paradigms for problem framing and creative thinking.

column3: Applies craft standards by following established patterns, guidelines, and systems across interaction, visual design, and accessibility. Delivers clear, detailed, production-ready work and strengthens core craft skills through consistent execution. Produces work that meets established standards with feedback to improve consistency and attention to detail.
column4: Demonstrates mastery and elevates craft standards in practice, raising the quality of execution within the team. Improves consistency and quality through critique, feedback, and hands-on examples of high-quality work. Balances speed and quality, knowing when to polish and when to ship to learn.
column5: Codifies craft standards for a vertical by formalising patterns, quality expectations, and reusable approaches that emerge from practice. Ensures coherence across the vertical, reducing fragmentation and inconsistencies between teams. Turns implicit good design into explicit guidelines and mentors designers to consistently apply high-quality craft.
column6: Envisions the long-term craft direction for Deel Design, setting future-facing standards and shaping Deel's design identity. Defines and evolves design standards that improve accuracy, consistency, and quality at scale. Co-defines craft philosophy across Deel Design, establishing and maintaining craft governance. Sets the bar for design excellence at an industry level, representing Deel as a recognised craft leader.

column3: Communicates clearly within their immediate team, both verbally and in writing, articulating design decisions with clear intent and rationale. Explains decisions using shared artifacts and basic rationale. May require support or preparation to communicate effectively in more complex or high-stakes contexts.
column4: Clearly explains design decisions and trade-offs, supporting shared understanding across Product, Engineering, and adjacent functions. Uses storytelling, critique, and workshops to help the team align and move forward. Tailors explanations to the audience and manages expectations within their area of ownership.
column5: Influences alignment across a vertical through clear narrative and communication. Manages stakeholders across teams with minimal oversight. Coaches designers on communication and stakeholder management. Shapes shared understanding through compelling design narratives that connect choices to user impact and business outcomes.
column6: Leads complex, high-stakes conversations that drive alignment across teams and disciplines. Aligns senior stakeholders and executives through compelling storytelling and clear points of view. Communicates with authority in high-ambiguity contexts, using narrative strategically to navigate tension and enable high-quality decisions. Elevates the communication bar across Deel Design.

column3: Collaborates with other designers in their vertical, participating in critiques and working sessions with openness. Seeks and provides feedback constructively within their immediate team. Builds positive relationships by taking ownership of issues and collaborating with others.
column4: Facilitates collaboration within XFN team, helping discussions stay focused and productive. Builds shared understanding across Product, Engineering, and adjacent functions. Proactively seeks and provides feedback to strengthen team outcomes.
column5: Drives effective cross-team collaboration within a vertical, fostering alignment and shared ownership. Establishes norms for how designers and cross-functional partners work together. Strengthens relationships across teams to enhance quality and delivery.
column6: Sets the standard for collaboration across Deel Design and cross-functionally. Orchestrates collaboration across verticals, building systems and practices that enable effective cross-team partnership. Creates the structures and culture that enable seamless partnership across teams, functions, and geographies.

column3: Delivers assigned tasks reliably, meeting expectations for quality and timelines. Takes responsibility for their own work and follows through on feedback. Proactively flags blockers, risks, or issues as they arise and seeks guidance when needed. Demonstrates personal accountability within defined scope.
column4: Owns projects end-to-end, from problem understanding through delivery and iteration. Identifies challenges and opportunities within their scope and raises them proactively. Manages dependencies and coordinates with partners to keep work moving. Takes responsibility for outcomes post-launch and learns from impact.
column5: Leads problem spaces within a vertical, setting direction and defining success. Anticipates challenges and opportunities ahead of time, creating clarity before issues materialise. Makes prioritisation and trade-off decisions that unblock teams and maintain momentum. Takes accountability for progress and outcomes across teams.
column6: Drives company-level outcomes related to experience and customer impact. Steers initiatives across multiple verticals, aligning teams around shared outcomes. Makes high-judgement calls in ambiguous situations, balancing speed, quality, and impact. Sets the standard for ownership, accountability, and agency across the organisation. Anticipates long-term risks and shapes direction before problems surface.

column3: Aligns with Deel values and applies them consistently in day-to-day work. Contributes to their direct design team culture, participating in team rituals, critiques, and shared practices. Demonstrates curiosity and openness by experimenting with ideas, inspiration, and tools (including AI) to improve quality and thinking.
column4: Reinforces Deel values consistently through decisions and collaboration. Strengthens team culture, actively helping to shape, maintain and evolve rituals, norms, and ways of working. Applies new tools or technologies where they meaningfully improve how the team works or what it can deliver. Responds effectively to shifting priorities with minimal supervision.
column5: Shapes Design Org culture within a vertical, driving initiatives that improve how designers work and grow. Identifies cultural gaps across teams and leads efforts to address them. Invests time in coaching and supporting designers. Turns successful experiments into repeatable approaches that others can build on. Thrives in ambiguous or rapidly evolving contexts.
column6: Defines the long-term Design Org culture alongside Design Leaders. Evolves culture across domains as the organisation scales and changes. Embeds culture into hiring, progression, recognition, and leadership expectations. Builds a culture where experimentation, learning, and reimagining the possible are core to how design operates. Influences how teams adapt and evolve practices through consistent example.
